title: Keswick to Threlkeld Railway Path Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Malc McDonald / Keswick Station
images.caption: Keswick Station. The railway to Keswick was closed to trains in 1972, but the station building survives. Part of the trackbed forms a section of the C2C (Sea to Sea) cycle route, one of the first on the National Cycle Network

images.title: Ian Capper / Greta bridges – Threlkeld Bridge
images.caption: Greta bridges  Threlkeld Bridge Between the former Keswick and Threlkeld stations, the disused Cockermouth, Keswick and Penrith Railway crossed the River Greta no fewer than 8 times in a distance of only 4 miles. All these bridges are of the bow-string girder construction, of various sizes and alignments. In addition, the same stretch saw it crossing the Greta's main feeder, the River Glenderamackin, although the bridge here is of a simpler design.

images.title: Ian Capper / Greta bridges – Threlkeld Bridge
images.caption: This is Threlkeld Bridge on the old A594, now bypassed by the A66, from which this photo is taken. What is interesting about this bridge is that it is at the junction of the River Glenderamackin (which comes in from the left through the left hand arch of the bridge), St Johns Beck (which comes in from the right through the right hand arch of the bridge and the River Greta, which is the combined river flowing towards the photographers position  so arguably a bridge over three rivers!

images.title: Mick Garratt / Disused Railway Tunnel, Keswick Cycleway
images.caption: Disused Railway Tunnel, Keswick Cycleway. The tunnel was used to carry the Penrith to Keswick railway and was block during the construction of the A66 Keswick bypass. At this point on the cycleway a wooden platform has been constructed overhanging the narrow gorge of the River Greta in order to get round the obstruction.

images.title: brian gillman / CC BY (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0)
images.caption: Old railway bridge nearing Threlkeld from Keswick.

images.title: Alex Robinson / Cycling through old railway tunnel
images.caption: Cycling through old railway tunnel

images.title: Looking across the Greta valley by David Purchase, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking across the Greta valley at the eastern end of the route near Threlkeld.

description: Enjoy an easy cycle or walk along the Keswick Railway Path in the Lake District National Park. The tree lined path runs along the trackbed of the old Cockermouth, Keswick and Penrith railway, following the River Greta from Keswick to Threlkeld. It's great for families as it's a nice easy cycle ride with a flat and well defined path. Walkers can enjoy the path too as it makes for a super riverside stroll. The latter part of the video below gives a good commentary on the railway path and shows the lovely scenery you can expect to see on the route. This includes the beautiful tree-clad Greta Gorge and views of the magnificent Blencathra mountain. Near to the route is the fascinating Castlerigg Stone Circle. Often thought of as the Stonehenge of the Lake District the ancient stone circle is located just to the south of the path and is well worth a visit. To extend your walk you climb to the nearby Latrigg Fell and enjoy great views over the area.
